chief_complaint.onset: Started 3 days ago during rock climbing.
chief_complaint.progression: Pain has worsened with activity and slightly improved with rest.

symptoms.pain_type: Sharp pain during movement, dull ache at rest

functional_limitations.work: Mild discomfort while typing for extended periods.
functional_limitations.daily_tasks: Difficulty washing hair, lifting objects overhead, and dressing.
functional_limitations.hobbies: Unable to climb or perform yoga poses requiring arm elevation.

previous_injuries: Ankle sprain during jogging (3 years ago)
medical_history.medications: Occasional use of ibuprofen for lower back pain.
medical_history.family_history: No hereditary musculoskeletal or connective tissue disorders.

social_history.support_system: Friends are available for help occasionally.
social_history.alcohol_consumption: Occasional, 1-2 glasses of wine per week

observation.appearance: Mild swelling over the shoulder; no visible discoloration.

range_of_motion.active: Limited in abduction and external rotation.
range_of_motion.passive: Mild pain with end-range external rotation.

palpation.pain_points: Tenderness over the anterior shoulder and lateral deltoid region.

xray.notes: Slight narrowing of the subacromial space, indicating potential impingement.

ultrasound.result: Inflammation and thickening of the supraspinatus tendon.
ultrasound.notes: No complete tears detected; mild bursal fluid observed.

mri.result: Partial-thickness tear of the supraspinatus tendon, with mild edema.
mri.notes: No labral tear detected; normal scapular alignment.

key_findings: Limited active and passive external rotation.
Positive Hawkins-Kennedy and Neer tests suggest subacromial impingement.
Partial-thickness tear of the supraspinatus visible on MRI.

suggested_lines_of_inquiry: Ask about the specific motion that caused the pain during climbing.
Investigate clicking sounds during movement and their location.
Correlate positive special test results with imaging findings.
useful_notes: MRI findings of partial-thickness tear and mild edema align with clinical tests.
Absence of labral involvement excludes diagnoses like SLAP tears.
